abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of outcome is
            satisfactory, sustainability likely, and institutional
            development impacts substantial. Major lessons are as
            follows. A participatory project design should focus on the
            process, rather than on physical targets, although clearly,
            informed assumptions have to be made for the purpose of
            estimating costs, and returns. In this case, the design
            should have allowed for an annual cycle of work, starting
            from participatory micro catchment planning, while the ratio
            between conservation, and supporting income-generating
            expenditure should be further addressed. While the project
            delivered an infrequent, and invaluable lesson in the
            successful collaboration between implementing agencies, it
            also showed that key elements within such cooperation (and
            that of villagers) are time, and training, requiring
            flexibility to accommodate each agency's contribution
            to its fullest extent. Despite successes, legal
            uncertainties surrounded the rangeland, particularly the
            non-forest rangeland, aggravated by an inadequate legal
            framework for the Ministry of Agriculture's
            participation in related activities. Nonetheless, the
            exemplary approach taken by project design, and
            implementation is worth noting, which built on existing
            local technology, and capacity, thus enhancing the
            employment of its farmer-centered problem-census
            problem-solving approach, in a sensitive manner. Further
            lessons reinforce the need for social, and extension skills
            provision, stakeholder participation, training appropriately
            timed, monitoring and evaluation performance criteria, as
            well as the provision of technical expertise.
